ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would highly recommend this course, or any other course with Professor LeVen. As a bridge course, this class focused on learning how to read Greek with some fluency and therefore included some review of grammatical concepts. However, there was also a generous amount of discussion of the texts as literature. Professor LeVen has high standards for student performance, which means that a course with her will make you improve your Greek. (This is wonderful and most appreciated.) She accommodates the course's demands to students' needs, though, and is never unfair. She's also a delightful person to have as a professor. She has a good sense of humor, cares about her students, and is very easy to contact by e-mail or in office hours.

I would not recommend this class if you are already taking Latin. I would also not recommend it if you do not have a great amount of experience with the Ancient Greek canon. Get yourself in good stead with Plato, Homer, and Thucydides first. Lucian spends a lot of time satirizing these authors, so it would be more fulfilling to encounter them first.
This class is awesome. You'll learn a lot, and Professor LeVen is amazing. Lucian is also a fascinating guy. If you're on the fence about this class, don't be: take it.
Definitely. Professor LeVen is wonderful and Lucian is fairly straightforward. Just be prepared to look up a lot of vocabulary.
